Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Provide emotional support and companionship to patients
Situation2: A patient has just received a difficult diagnosis and is visibly distressed and crying.
Story: I sat in the break room, my phone buzzing with another message from my husband. He needed me—his words were raw, desperate. He was unraveling after the news about his father, and I was the only one he wanted to talk to. My heart ached to be there, to hold him, to reassure him that we’d get through this together. But just as I started to type a reply, the call bell rang from Room 204. Mrs. Evans, my patient, had just learned her cancer had returned. When I entered, she was sobbing, clutching the thin hospital blanket, her eyes searching mine for comfort. She needed me, too—needed my words, my presence, my strength. I felt torn in two, the weight of both their pain pressing down on me. My husband’s messages kept coming, each one more urgent, while Mrs. Evans’s tears fell silently, her hand reaching for mine. I stood there, caught between the two worlds, my heart pulled in opposite directions, unsure which need to answer first.
